title-group.article-title: Hybrid Carotid Stent for the Management of a Venous Aneurysm of the Sigmoid Sinus Treated by Sole Stenting

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Neurosurgery, Specialties Hospital, Centro Médico Nacional “La Raza”, Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico
2Department of Endovascular Therapy, Comprehensive Stroke Unit, Hospital Angeles of the Pedregal, Mexico
3Department of Neurosurgery, Instituto Nacional de Ciencias Médicas y Nutrición, Mexico City

5Department of Neurological Endovascular Therapy, Instituto Nacional de Neurología y de Neurocirugía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico City, Mexico

author-notes.corresp: J. A. Santos-Franco, Department of Neurosurgery, Specialties Hospital, Centro Médico Nacional La Raza, Seris y Zaachila, Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico 00295, Mexico Email: jasantosfranco@hotmail.com

abstract.p: We describe the case of a 59-year-old female presenting with a disabling pulsatile tinnitus caused by a venous aneurysm of the sigmoid sinus. This is the first successful case of sole stenting, using a closed-cell design in the central part of the stent, leading to the occlusion of the aneurysm and the cure of the tinnitus. Venous aneurysms of the dural sinuses are rare causes of pulsatile tinnitus and the sole stenting technique provides a simpler, safe, and effective approach.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pulsatile tinnitus is a condition that can be disabling. One cause which has rarely been described is the presence of a venous aneurysm of the sigmoid sinus. We describe the case of a 59-year-old female treated with only 1 stent placement.

sec.title: Case Presentation
sec.p: This 59-year-old female had pulsatile tinnitus for the last 20 years. The symptoms were intermittent at the beginning, but they became bilateral and disabling, causing sleeping difficulties and suicidal ideas. The physical examination found a normal tympanic membrane, no vascular mass, no hearing impairment, and a bruit in the right mastoid region, synchronous with heartbeat; other thoracic or cervical bruits that might have been perceived as the cause of the tinnitus were ruled out, and the manual compression of the right jugular vein decreased the bruit. Neurological examination was otherwise unremarkable.

The computed tomography (CT) showed an erosion of the bony groove housing the sigmoid sinus, distal to the transverse sinus, and pointing to the mastoid cells (Figure 1, panels A and C). This osseous defect was enhanced by contrast administration, as did the transverse and sigmoid sinuses (Figure 1, panels B and D). Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) in the venous phase showed a venous aneurysm of the sigmoid sinus, distal to the sinodural angle (Figure 2, panels A and B), with a stenosis of the distal portion of the transverse sinus, probably due to arachnoid granulation (Figure 2, panels A and B).

caption.p: Preoperative workup. Axial computed tomography (CT) scan with osseous (A) and contrast-enhanced (B) views, comparing the canal of the right (hollow arrow) and the left sigmoid sinus (thin arrow). Asymmetry is evident and the injection of dye opacifies the aneurysm. Coronal osseous (C) and contrast-enhanced (D) views show similar findings, but the bone defect seems much larger.

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) views of the procedure. A and B, Pretreatment. A, Lateral and B, Anteroposterior views. Stenosis of the distal portion of the transverse sinus (thick arrow); venous aneurysm (hollow arrow), slightly distal to the transverse/sigmoid sinus junction. The drainage of the vein of Labbé can be seen in A (dotted arrow). C and D, Stenting procedure. C, Undeployed stent (thin arrow) is shown, covering the neck of the aneurysm (hollow arrow). D, Stent was deployed (limits marked by arrows; radiopaque markers by dotted arrows). E and F, Immediate postoperative runs: Projections are similar to panels A and B. E, lateral and F, anteroposterior views. The venous aneurysm has disappeared. The stenotic part of the transverse sinus is normalized (thick arrow). The vein of Labbé is preserved (dotted arrow in E), in spite of draining into a stented portion.

sec.p: An endovascular approach was planned, inspired by the technique described by Zenteno. 1 The procedure was performed under neuroleptoanalgesia and local analgesia, puncturing the femoral artery and vein to place sheaths of 5F and 6 F, respectively. A JB 2 5F diagnostic catheter (Terumo Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) and a 6F guider guiding catheter (Boston Scientific, Natick, Massachusetts) were placed in the internal carotid artery and the vein jugular in the right side. A road mapping injected from the arterial side but fixed at the venous phase allowed to visualize the involved dural sinuses.

A microcatheter (Excelsior SL10, Boston Scientific) over a 0.014” microguidewire (Transend, Boston Scientific) was navigated from the venous side to selectively catheterize the superior sagittal sinus. Tirofiban was administered with a loading infusion of (0.4 µg/kg per min for 30 minutes) followed by maintenance at 0.1 µg/kg per min, and an exchange maneuver using a 0.014” × 300 cm microguidewire (Transend, Boston Scientific) allowed a retrograde placement of a carotid self-expandable Cristallo Ideale stent (Medtronic, Invatec, Roncadelle, Bs, Italy). The device was of 11 mm × 30 mm and was deployed from the distal portion of the transverse sinus to the sigmoid sinus, recovering the neck of the lesion with the central part of the stent (Figure 2, panels C and D). The proximal part of the stent was deployed perpendicularly to the main axis of the transverse sinus. In the postoperative runs, the aneurysm did not opacify and the stenotic portion of the transverse sinus was expanded (Figure 2, panels E and F). No complications were seen and the vein of Labbe remained patent. The tinnitus notably decreased at the end of the procedure and had completely disappeared at 24 hours. The patient was discharged with oral antiplatelet drugs (clopidogrel 75 mg every day [qd] and acetyl salicylic acid 100 mg qd). A control CT angiogram at 1 month showed patency of the stent. At 6 months of follow-up, the patient remains asymptomatic and imaging shows complete occlusion of the aneurysm, patency of the stent, and preservation of the vein of Labbe (Figure 3).

caption.p: Follow-up imaging at 6 months. A (anteroposterior) and B (lateral) computed-tomography angiograms show patency of the sinus and of the stent. Closed-cell structure at the center (curly brackets) are distinguished from open-cell structure at the tips (white arrows in A; black dotted arrows in B). C (lateral) and D (anteroposterior) DSA at confirm patency of the stent, the sinus, occlusion of the aneurysm, and normal drainage of the vein of Labbé.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Tinnitus is always a therapeutic challenge to the physician. 2 A pulsatile pattern suggests a vascular cause, and the nonpathological causes include aberrant internal carotid artery, a high or dehiscent jugular bulb, or a jugular megabulb deformity. 3,4 Pathological causes of pulsatile tinnitus should be ruled out: jugular glomus, dural arteriovenous malformations, acquired stenosis or aberrant course of the internal carotid artery, carotid-cavernous fistulae, and head and neck arteriovenous malformations. 3 –5

An aneurysm or diverticulum of the sigmoid/transverse sinus is an extremely uncommon entity revealed by disabling pulsatile tinnitus, and only 12 previous cases have been reported 1,6
–11 (Table 1); we also include a case reported by Mehall as a laterally placed sigmoid sinus, where the angiography reveals in fact an aneurysm of the junction of the transverse/sigmoid sinus 3 ; his patient received no treatment.

caption.p: Reported Cases of Intracranial Venous Aneurysms of a Dural Sinus Manifesting With Tinnitus

fn.p: Abbreviations: T, transverse sinus; S, sigmoid sinus; T-S, transverse–sigmoid sinus junction; bil, bilateral.

sec.p: Two different approaches for the management of such lesions have been described: surgical and endovascular. Otto et al have described a series of 5 patients, 3 of them were operated using a transmastoid approach and skeletonization of the sinus harboring the aneurysm, and extraluminal compression with muscle or bone wax fragments. 8 Recently, Gologorsky et al reported another surgical case treated by a retromastoid incision and skeletonization of the right transverse sinus, electrocoagulation of the aneurysm, and placement of U clips. 9

The endovascular technique was pioneered by the team of Lariboisière in Paris, as Houdart et al were the first to report simple coiling of a narrow neck aneurysm of the left sigmoid sinus. 6 A stent-assisted coiling technique was used by other authors: Sanchez et al in Brazil report the embolization of a wide-neck aneurysm of the sigmoid sinus 7 ; Zenteno et al in Mexico City tried to use the sole stenting technique which had already been used in intracranial arterial aneurysms several years before. 12 In a first step, a carotid wall stent (Boston Scientific) was placed through a paratorcular burr hole to the right transverse sinus. The experience of the Mexican team since the end of the 90s in the sole stenting technique for arterial aneurysms led Zenteno et al to think that the stent might be sufficient to promote thrombosis of the venus aneurysm. 4 Actually, the volume of the decreased and the tinnitus disappeared but recurred later. In a second step, the aneurysm was further coiled with Guglielmi detachable coils (GDC, Boston Scientific, Natick, MA, USA) 1

The cause of “repermeabilization” was not elucidated. In intracranial berry aneurysms, the stent promotes deviation of the flow, proportionally to the percentage of metal surface covering the neck of the lesion and to the correction of hemodynamic and geometric patterns, if we translate this knowledge to the cranial venous sinuses, we ought to think that the sole stenting technique might be favored by the velocity and pressure of blood, much lower than in arteries. In the present case, the reasons to chose a Cristallo Ideale stent (Medtronic) were low profile, better navigability as it is a hybrid stent—open-cell structure at the tips and closed-cell at the center, with in vitro low penetration of particles. 13 Mathis et al illustrate how a wall stent (Boston Scientific) can also navigate via a transjugular route to treat a stenosis of the transverse sinus. 14 However, other authors find this maneuver risky, like Zenteno et al, where this navigation was declined and a transosseous paratorcular approach was preferred. 1 We also thought that the tortuosity was not compatible with the rigidity of the wall stent. Additionally, to avoid a failure of the technique and further coiling, we tried to increase the percentage of metal coverage at the neck of the lesion to promote modification of blood flow. Our choice was based on 2 facts: (1) the center of the Cristallo Ideale stent is a closed-cell structure, (2) the diameter of the device was chosen 3 mm above the theoretical diameter of the sinus. A rapid and persistent occlusion of the aneurysm was thus obtained, leading to the healing of the tinnitus. A technical flaw was the inadequate length of the stent, with a transverse sinus insufficiently covered, leading to a lack of parallelism to the dural walls (panels C of Figures 2 and 3), the clinical efficacy was nevertheless not affected.

The use of a covered stent may seem attractive in those cases, and Choi et al successfully placed a similar device in the transverse sinus for the management of dural fistula, 15 but the proximity of the vein of Labbe to the aneurysm, discouraged us from taking the risk of dural sinus occlusion.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Aneurysms of the transverse and/or sigmoid sinuses are uncommon and are revealed by a disabling pulsatile tinnitus. As with every rare disorder, no large series with significant and conclusive results for the management can be found. However, the endovascular technique is faster, requires no general anesthesia, and the risk of tearing the sinuses is decreased. We should consider these procedures as functional neurosurgery, because the patients are otherwise healthy. This is the first successful case of venous aneurysm of an intracranial sinus treated with the sole stenting technique, which seems safer, faster, and less expensive than other endovascular or surgical approaches.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
